posts.name: CJ Hill
posts.cooked:
This will be our third year with swerve.  Currently we account for a random startup orientation by manually setting the heading with a command that resets the gyro (and we also implement a keep_angle() function to correct for swerve orientation drift).  We use the navX. The 2024 code is here and initial 2025 code is here .

Prior assumptions that we want to challenge:

In order to drive field-oriented, we need to set the heading of the robot

The heading needs to be set by the gyro if we want to correct for orientation drift

The gyro should be manually reset with the robot in the position you want aligned with wpilib’s field X to do the standard  field-oriented joystick control

The odometry should be updated from the gyro’s measurement, e.g. self.pose_estimator.updateWithTime(wpilib.Timer.getFPGATimestamp(), Rotation2d.fromDegrees(self.get_angle()), self.get_module_positions(),)

If you have apriltags you can get your initial pose at boot and update the pose with .addVisionMeasurement() so autos work (that’s what we do but it doesn’t help us with manual orientation yet)

In order to make field orientation work in teleop, we always had the driver orient the robot pointing to the opposite alliance wall and call a command that performed the .reset() function of the navX.  We’ve tried passing angles to the navX’s .setAngleAdjustment() manually and experimented with a (possibly circular?) way of resetting the gyro based on the pose but haven’t gotten that to work yet.

I’ve seen some posts where teams carry an offset from the expected startup orientation in auto.  In that approach I think you add the robot’s initial angular offset to your get_angle() function.  With april tags we could find and update that offset at teleop init or update it during disabled.  We could still align and reset manually if we wanted to because we’d just need to update that offset to zero at that point.  (I’d like to know if this approach is working well for others, and if the offset interferes with pose updates.)

Can you tell me which assumptions are wrong, and are there other ways this orientation could be implemented so it is simpler / seamless?  We have have the correct pose when we enable from apriltags and think this should be enough info to solve our problem.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
Why can’t you do #5 periodically when april tags are visible ( more than 1 tag to increase accuracy )?  You  could update your pose and check if you have a valid tags and addvisionmeasurement to your pose estimator accordingly.  This is not something that can only be done in autonomous. Think about how you could update that periodic ally.

A note on the offsets those are absolute encoder offsets that are updating your relative encoders in the motor controller. Relative motor encoders will set to 0 on power no matter the orientation ( effectively setting that position too zero), absolute encoders will retain there position without power.

posts.name: CJ Hill
posts.cooked: I don’t think I specified the question clearly.  We don’t have any problem reading apriltags and updating pose based on them.  What we can’t currently figure out how to do is automatically update the heading for field-oriented teleop driving at the start of the match.  We want to drop the robot on the field in an arbitrary orientation, get pose from the tags (done), and then when we start to do fileld oriented drive in teleop not have to manually set the orientation and reset the gyro.

I’m like 90% sure your problem is that you’re resetting your gyro in the first place. At least in Java (and I really doubt this would be different between languages), WPILIB handles offsetting the gyro for you.

posts.name: Alex
CJ Hill
posts.cooked: @VimalBuckley how do you set your initial heading for field-centric driving?

Here is a link to our swerve code (in java, but it looks to be the same general api in python).

We never reset our gyro itself. In order to reset our initial heading, we reset our robot pose, either from april tags or the starting pose of our auto if we can’t see any tags to update our pose.

In our resetPose method, we only use the SwerveDrivePoseEstimator’s resetPosition method, we don’t reset our gyro. Same thing for our resetHeading method.

When we want to move field centric, the robotAngle we pass into ChassisSpeeds.fromFieldRelativeSpeeds is the angle from our pose estimator, not our gyro.

Hope this helps!

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
Our driving inputs on a xbox are the left joystick controls strafe/translation , and the right joystick controls the rotation. we pass the right joystick values of the right joystick y component into our drive as the rotation.

translation = left joystick components rotation = right joystick component ( y or x component only thats up to you ) currentHeading = swerveDrivePoseEstimator.getEstimatedPosition().getRotation();
